questions.text: Characteristic cardiac lesion in SLE is
questions.solution:
The characteristic cardiac lesions of SLE are verrucous valvular abnormalities known as Libman-Sacks endocarditis.

They most often are located on the left-sided cardiac valves, particularly on the ventricular surface of the posterior mitral leaflet, and are made up almost entirely of fibrin.

However, Pericarditis is the most common cardiac manifestation of SLE.

questions.text: Cogan syndrome includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Interstitial nephritis is not a part of Cogan’s syndrome.

Cogan’s syndrome is a primary vasculitis syndrome.

It includes

  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Vestibuloauditory symptoms
  • Systemic vasculitis, particularly aortitis with involvement of the aortic valve. Glucocorticoids are the mainstay of treatment.

questions.text: The deformity present in the below given image of transthoracic echocardiography is seen in
questions.solution:
The above given image shows “Hockey stick” or “elbow” deformity seen in case of mitral stenosis usually seen in chronic rheumatic heart disease.

“Hockey stick” or an “elbow” deformity is seen in diastolic image of transthoracic echocardiography:

  • Leaflet thickening
  • Restriction of the anterior mitral valve leaflet tip
  • Doming of the body of the leaflet toward the interventricular septum.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of classical triad of ECG changes in pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade
questions.solution:
Prolonged ST segment is not a part of classic triad of ECG findings for pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade.

  • Classical triad of ECG changes in pericardial effusion with cardiac tamponade includes:
    • Sinus tachycardia
    • Low QRS voltages
    • Electrical alternans (best seen in leads V3 and V4 in this case; arrows)
  • This triad is highly specific for pericardial effusion, usually with tamponade physiology, but of limited sensitivity

questions.text: Most commonly involved vessel in case of leukocytoclastic angiitis is
questions.solution:
Postcapillary venules are the most commonly involved vessels in leukocytoclastic angiitis.

Leukocytoclastic angiitis:

  • Also known as cutaneous vasculitis/hypersensitivity vasculitis/cutaneous leukocytoclastic angiitis.
  • Defined as the inflammation of the blood vessels of the dermis.
  • Postcapillary venules are the most commonly involved vessels; capillaries and arterioles may be involved less frequently.
  • The typical histopathologic feature of cutaneous vasculitis is the presence of vasculitis of small vessels.
  • This vasculitis is characterized by a leukocytoclasis.
  • Clinical feature:
    • Predominance of skin involvement mainly in the form of palpable purpura.
    • Other cutaneous manifestations of the vasculitis may occur, including macules, papules, vesicles, bullae, subcutaneous nodules, ulcers, and recurrent or chronic urticaria.
    • Pruritic or even quite painful, with a burning or stinging sensation.
  • Most commonly site:
    • Lower extremities in ambulatory patients
    • Sacral area in bedridden patients due to the effects of hydrostatic forces on the postcapillary venules.
  • Lab features:
    • Mild leukocytosis with or without eosinophilia
    • Elevated ESR
  • Diagnostic feature:
    • Demonstration of vasculitis on biopsy

questions.text: A 70 year old male presented with severe pain in knee joint of acute onset. On examination - knee was red, swollen and tender. X ray of knee showed linear calcification. Definitive diagnosis requires

choices.text: Demonstration of positive birefringent rhomboid crystals in synovial fluid

questions.solution:
Diagnosis of given case scenario is calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease.

Factors favoring diagnosis are:

  • Most common in elderly.
  • Knee joint is most commonly affected.
  • Radiographs or ultrasound reveal punctate and/or linear radiodense deposits within fibrocartilaginous joint menisci or articular hyaline cartilage (chondrocalcinosis).

Definitive diagnosis requires demonstration of typical rhomboid or rodlike crystals (generally weakly positively birefringent or nonbirefringent with polarized light) in synovial fluid or articular tissue.

questions.text: Bode index is used in
questions.solution:
BODE index is related to lung transplantation.

BODE stands for

  • Body mass index
  • Airflow Obstruction
  • Dyspnea
  • Exercise capacity

questions.text: False about CURB-65 criteria to assess pneumonia severity is
questions.solution:
CURB-65 includes systolic blood pressure ≤ 90 mmHg as criteria, not ≤ 100 mmHg.

The CURB-65 is used to assess the severity of pneumonia.

It includes five variables:

  • Confusion
  • Urea >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg
  • Age ≥65 years

questions.text: Most common symptom of lung cancer
questions.solution:
Cough is the most common presenting feature in a case of lung carcinoma followed by weight loss.

Presenting Signs and Symptoms of Lung Cancer:

Symptom and Signs Range of Frequency
Cough 8–75%
Weight loss 0–68%
Dyspnea 3–60%
Chest pain 20–49%
Hemoptysis 6–35%
Bone pain 6–25%
Clubbing 0–20%
Fever 0–20%
Weakness 0–10%
Superior vena cava obstruction 0–4%
Dysphagia 0–2%
Wheezing and stridor 0–2%

questions.text: Structure extensively degenerated in paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration is:
questions.solution:
• Paraneoplastic cerebellar degeneration occurs due to extensive degeneration of Purkinje cells, with variable involvement of other cerebellar cortical neurons, deep cerebellar nuclei, and spinocerebellar tracts.
  • The tumors more frequently involved are
  • SCLC (P/Q-type voltage-gated calcium channels)
  • Cancer of the breast and ovary (Anti-Yo antibodies)
  • Hodgkin’s lymphoma (anti-Tr antibodies)

questions.text: The given ECG shows
questions.solution:
• The given ECG shows changes corresponding with pulmonary embolism.
  • Changes are
    • Sinus tachycardia
    • S1Q3T3 pattern (T-wave inversion in III)
    • Incomplete RBBB
    • Right precordial T-wave inversions
  • Consistent with acute RV overload in a patient with pulmonary emboli

questions.text: Most common site of anomaly depicted in the below given image, whose histological section shows a persistent caliber artery present in the submucosa is?
questions.solution:
• The above given image shows actively spurting Dieulafoy’s lesion.
  • There is no underlying mucosal lesion.
  • Histological picture shows persistent caliber artery present in the gastric submucosa, immediately beneath the mucosa.
  • Hence the diagnosis is Dieulafoy’s Lesion.
  • It is seen most commonly on the lesser curvature of the proximal stomach.
  • It also called persistent caliber artery - a large-caliber arteriole that runs immediately beneath the gastrointestinal mucosa and bleeds through pinpoint mucosal erosion.
  • Often recognized only after repeated endoscopy for recurrent bleeding.
  • Treatment:
    • Endoscopic therapy, such as thermal coagulation or band ligation
    • Angiographic embolization or surgical oversewing where endoscopic therapy has failed.

questions.text: Identify the endoscopic image
questions.solution:
• The endoscopy image shows presence of linear furrows and multiple corrugated rings throughout a narrowed esophagus called feline esophagus or trachealization of the esophagus.
  • It suggests diagnosis of eosinophilic esophagitis.
  • The diagnosis requires biopsy with histologic finding of > 15–20 eosinophils per high-power field.

questions.text: Best investigation for metastatic gastrinoma is
questions.solution:
• Octreoscan with sensitivity of 80-100% is the best investigation to detect metastatic gastrinomas.
  • It is based in the principle that several types of endocrine tumors express cell-surface receptors for somatostatin.
  • This permits the localization of gastrinomas by measuring the uptake of the stable somatostatin analogue111 In-pentreotide (OctreoScan) with sensitivity and specificity rates of >85%.

questions.text: Triple A syndrome includes all of the following except
questions.solution:
Achlorhydria is not a part of triple A syndrome.

Triple A syndrome is due to mutation in AAAS gene.

It includes:

  • Alacrimia
  • Achalasia
  • Addison’s disease

questions.text: Beck’s triad is seen in
questions.solution:
Beck’s triad is seen in cardiac tamponade.

It includes:

  • Hypotension
  • Soft or absent heart sounds
  • Jugular venous distention with a prominent x descent but an absent y descent.

questions.text: The triad of saturnine gout, hypertension and renal failure is seen in
questions.solution:
• The triad of “saturnine gout,” hypertension, and renal insufficiency should prompt a practitioner to ask specifically about lead exposure.
  • Heavy metals like lead or cadmium lead to proximal tubule dysfunction.

questions.text: All are true about recovery phase of Acute Kidney Injury except
questions.solution:
Hyponatremia is seen in recovery phase of acute kidney injury.

Stages of AKI:

  • Initiation phase
    • Decrease in urine output
  • Maintenance phase
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hyperkalemia
    • Hyperphosphataemia
    • Hypomagnesemia
    • Hypocalcaemia
    • Metabolic acidosis
    • Elevation of BUN
  • Recovery/diuretic phase 
    • Hyponatremia
    • Hypokalemia
    • Hypophosphataemia
    • Hypomagnesaemia
    • Hypocalcaemia

questions.text: Most common acute complication during hemodialysis is
questions.solution: Hypotension is the most common acute complication of hemodialysis, particularly among patients with diabetes mellitus.

questions.text: False about pre-renal acute renal failure is
questions.solution:
In case of pre-renal acute renal failure, blood urea nitrogen/plasma creatinine ratio will be > 20.

Differences between pre-renal and intrinsic renal failure:

Index   Pre-renal failure   Intrinsic renal failure
BUN/Plasma creatinine ratio >20:1 10–15:1
Urine osmolality (mosmol/L H2O) >500 <350
Urine sodium UNa (meq/L) <20 >40
Fractional excretion of sodium <1% >2%
Urine/plasma creatinine (UCr/PCr) >40 <20
Urinalysis (casts) None or hyaline/ granular Muddy brown

questions.text: The most common neurological disorder seen in chronic renal failure patients is
questions.solution:
Polyneuropathy is the most common neurological disorder seen in about 60% of patients with CKD.

It is characterized by

  • Length-dependent numbness
  • Tingling
  • Allodynia
  • Mild distal weakness

The sensorimotor polyneuropathy can be stabilized by hemodialysis and improved with successful renal transplantation.

questions.text: Not a part of “Triple therapy” immunosuppression for post-renal transplant patient is
questions.solution:
Belatacept is not part of “Triple therapy” immunosuppression for post-renal transplant patient.

  • The most frequently used combination is triple therapy with
    • Prednisone
    • Calcineurin inhibitor (Tacrolimus - 1st line or Cyclosporine)
    • Antimetabolite (Mycophenolate mofetil or Azathioprine)
  • Mammalian TOR (mTOR) inhibitors can replace one of the last two agents.

Note: More recently, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved a new co-stimulatory blocking antibody (CD80 & CD86), belatacept, as a new strategy to prevent long-term calcineurin inhibitor toxicity. It is indicated for prophylaxis of organ rejection in patients who are EBV seropositive and receiving a kidney transplant.

questions.text: A patient with breast carcinoma presents with nephrotic syndrome. Renal biopsy is likely to reveal
questions.solution:
Most carcinomas cause secondary membranous glomerulonephritis.

Membranous glomerulo nephritis:

  • Primary/idiopathic membranous glomerulonephritis
  • Secondary membranous glomerulonephritis
    • Infection: Hepatitis B and C, syphilis, malaria, schistosomiasis, leprosy, filariasis
    • Cancer: Breast, colon, lung, stomach, kidney, esophagus, neuroblastoma
    • Drugs: Gold, mercury, penicillamine, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory agents, probenecid
    • Autoimmune diseases: Systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, primary biliary cirrhosis, dermatitis herpetiformis, bullous pemphigoid, myasthenia gravis, Sjogren’s syndrome, Hashimoto’s thyroiditis.
    • Other systemic diseases: Fanconi’s syndrome, sickle cell anemia, diabetes, Crohn’s disease, sarcoidosis, Guillain-Barre syndrome, Weber-Christian disease, angiofollicular lymph node hyperplasia.

questions.text: What is the most common mutation in cystic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
In cystic fibrosis, CFTR mutations that disrupt protein maturation are termed class II defects and are by far the most common genetic abnormalities.

There are 6 classes of defects involving the CFTR gene:

Class Defect
Class I Absence of synthesis e.g., W1282X, G542X
Class II Defective protein maturation and premature degradation e.g., F508 deletion
Class III Disordered gating/regulation e.g., G551D mutation
Class IV Defective conductance through the ion channel pore
Class V Promoter or splicing abnormality leading to reduced CFTR transcripts
Class VI Accelerated turnover from the cell surface

questions.text: DLco is decreased in all of the following conditions except
questions.solution:
DLco is increased in pulmonary haemorrhage – hemoglobin present in erythrocytes combine with CO which results in reduced concentration of CO in exhaled air. Hence DLco is increased.

Diffusing Capacity (Dlco):

  • This test uses a small (and safe) amount of carbon monoxide (CO) to measure gas exchange across the alveolar membrane during a 10-sec breath hold.
  • CO in exhaled breath is analyzed to determine the quantity of CO crossing the alveolar membrane and combining with hemoglobin in red blood cells.
  • It increases with the increase in
    • Surface area available for diffusion and
    • The amount of hemoglobin within the capillaries
  • Varies inversely with alveolar membrane thickness
  • Thus, Dlco decreases in diseases that 
    • Thicken or destroy alveolar membranes (e.g., pulmonary fibrosis, emphysema)
    • Curtail the pulmonary vasculature (e.g., pulmonary hypertension)
    • Reduce alveolar capillary hemoglobin (e.g., anemia)
  • Single-breath diffusing capacity may be elevated in
    • Acute congestive heart failure
    • Asthma
    • Polycythemia
    • Pulmonary hemorrhage

questions.text: Type 3 respiratory failure occurs in
questions.solution:
Postoperative atelectasis causes type 3 respiratory failure.

Type III respiratory failure

  • Results from lung atelectasis.
  • Since atelectasis occurs commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure.
  • After general anesthesia, decrease in functional residual capacity lead to collapse of dependent lung units.
  • Treated by
    • Frequent changes in position
    • Chest physiotherapy
    • Upright positioning
    • Control of incisional and/or abdominal pain
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation - used to reverse regional atelectasis

questions.text: Most common type of bronchiectasis
questions.solution:
• Cylindrical or tubular is the most common form of bronchiectasis.
  • Other types are – varicose & cystic.

questions.text: Shohl’s solution is
questions.solution:
• Shohl’s solution is sodium citrate.
  • It is used in correction of metabolic acidosis and the Hypokalemia in case of classic dRTA.

questions.text: Most common cause of death in Menke’s disease
questions.solution:
Most common cause of death in case of menkes kinky hair syndrome is cardiac rupture.

Menkes kinky hair syndrome:

  • It is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism.
  • It is caused by mutations in the copper-transporting ATP7A gene.
  • It is characterized by
    • Mental retardation
    • Hypocupremia
    • Decreased circulating ceruloplasmin
  • Children with this disease often die within 5 years because of dissecting aneurysms or cardiac rupture
  • The diagnosis of copper deficiency is usually based on low serum levels of copper (<65 μg/dL) and low ceruloplasmin levels (<20 mg/dL)

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a major manifestation of unintentional weight loss?
questions.solution:
Osteopenia is not considered a major manifestation of unintentional weight loss (UWL).

The four major manifestations of unintentional weight loss are

  • Anorexia (loss of appetite)
  • Sarcopenia (loss of muscle mass)
  • Cachexia (a syndrome of weight loss, loss of muscle and adipose tissue, anorexia, and weakness)
  • Dehydration

questions.text: All are true about Miller fisher syndrome except
questions.solution:
Miller Fisher syndrome is characterized by Areflexia without muscle weakness.

  • Miller Fisher syndrome (MFS) is a variant of GBS.
  • It accounts for ~5% of all cases.
  • It is strongly associated with antibodies to the ganglioside GQ1b (IgG).
  • It presents with
    • Rapidly evolving ataxia
    • Areflexia of limbs without weakness
    • Ophthalmoplegia, often with pupillary paralysis

questions.text: Triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus doesn’t include
questions.solution:
Triad of NPH doesn’t include aphasia.

  • The clinical triad of NPH includes
    • An abnormal gait (ataxic or apractic)
    • Dementia (usually mild to moderate, with an emphasis on executive impairment)
    • Urinary urgency or incontinence
  • Neuroimaging reveals enlarged lateral ventricles (hydrocephalus) with little or no cortical atrophy, although the sylvian fissures may appear propped open (so-called “boxcarring”), which can be mistaken for perisylvian atrophy.

questions.text: The pulse waveform of a patient is given below. Which of the following conditions is the patient likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given pulse waveform shows two peaks in systole, indicating pulsus bisferiens. Of the given options, aortic regurgitation causes pulsus bisferiens.

In aortic regurgitation, the left ventricle receives extra blood due to the incompetent aortic valve, apart from the normal pulmonary venous blood coming from the left atrium. This large stroke volume when ejected with force causes the wall of the aorta to collapse due to the Venturi effect. This causes a midsystolic dip in the blood flow.

Other options:

Option B: Aortic stenosis causes pulsus parvus et tardus. The fixed obstruction of the aortic valve produces a slow rising pulse since the rate at which the blood can be ejected out of the left ventricle is restricted. 

Option C: Pericardial tamponade causes pulsus paradoxus. This is a misnomer, because pulsus paradoxus is actually an exaggerated fall in the sytolic blood pressure during inspiration, and has nothing to do with pulse. A fall of systolic BP up to 10 mmHg is seen in normal individuals during inspiration. In patients with pericardial tamponade, there is restricted filling of the left ventricle and thus the fall in systolic BP is more than 10 mmHg. 

Option D: In patients with severe left ventricle failure, alternating low and high volume pulse is seen.

questions.text: Paroxysmal AV block is associated with
questions.solution:
• Paroxysmal AV block are series of nonconducted P waves associated with Second-degree AV block (particularly type II).
  • It implies significant conduction system disease and is an indication for permanent pacing.

ECG shows multiple nonconducted P waves after a period of sinus bradycardia with a normal PR interval.

questions.text: DIC is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
M3 AML i.e. acute promyelocytic leukemia is associated with DIC.

Class Salient features
M0 – Minimally differentiated AML Myeloid lineage blasts
M1 – AML without maturation Myeloblasts without maturation (>3% blasts MPO or SBB positive)
M2 – AML with maturation t(8;21) Auer rods + Max incidence of chloroma
M3 – Acute promyelocytic leukemia t(15;17) Auer rods + Ass with DIC
M4 – Acute Myelomonocytic leukemia (Naegli type) Inversion 16
M5 – Acute monocytic leukemia (Schilling type) t(9;11) Tissue infiltrationOrganomegaly
M6 – Acute erythroleukemia (Di Gugleimo disease)  
M7 – Acute megakaryocytic leukemia As with myelofibrosis and Down syndrome

questions.text: A disease of which of the following systems is most likely to have resulted in this finding?
questions.solution:
The finding seen above is –Dahl’s sign/ Thinker’s sign/ Target sign

  • It is a seen as symmetric, slanting regions of hyperpigmentation on both thighs, as a result of repeated pressure from the elbows on the epidermis of the thighs in patient’s spending large amount of time in the tripod position.
  • Seen in patients with advanced COPD

questions.text:
Arterial blood gas analysis of a person with liver disease reveals the following results. What type of metabolic and/or respiratory abnormality is likely to be present?

PaCO2= 35

HCO3- = 32

pH = 7.5

Anion gap = 16

Na+ = 140

K+ = 4.0

Cl-= 91

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis and compensatory respiratory acidosis
Metabolic acidosis and compensatory respiratory alkalosis
Metabolic alkalosis and simultaneous respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given arterial blood gas (ABG) result shows metabolic alkalosis plus respiratory alkalosis.

ABG analysis is done to assess disturbances of the normal acid-base homeostasis. It is calculated using the following steps:

Step 1: Determine if acidemia or alkalemia is present. Acidemia is a blood pH below 7.35 and alkalemia is a blood pH above 7.45. 

The ABG given here shows a pH of 7.5 which is above the limit of 7.45. Thus there is alkalemia.

pH = 7.5 Increased  Normal - 7.35 to 7.45
PCO2 = 35 Normal  Normal - 35 to 45 mmHg
HCO3- = 32 Increased  Normal - 20 to 28 mEq/L

Step 2: Look for the cause of acidemia/alkalemia. Acidosis is the pathological process that causes an increase in hydrogen ions. Alkalosis is the pathological process that causes a decrease in hydrogen ions. 

Here, the value of HCO3- is 32 (increase in bicarbonate ions). PCO2 is within normal limits. Thus, the primary acid-base disorder is metabolic alkalosis. 

During a simple metabolic disorder, you would expect there to be respiratory compensation (and vice versa). 

The expected respiratory compensation during metabolic alkalosis is : PCO2 = (HCO3- ) + 15 or PCO2 increases by 6 mmHg for each 10mEq/L increase in HCO3- .  

Thus, the expected increase in PCO2 should be 32 + 15  = 47 mmHg. However, the PCO2 here is only 35 mmHg and hence there is no respiratory compensation.

Step 3: Since CO2 is 35, which is below the compensatory values, it suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Thus the ABG above shows a mixed disorder of metabolic alkalosis with simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

Related Pearl: Causes of Acid-Base Disorders

Metabolic acidosis

Metabolic alkalosis

Respiratory acidosis

Respiratory alkalosis

Ketoacidosis

Lactic acidosis

Chronic renal failure

Salicylate intoxication

Methanol/formaldehyde intoxication

Ethylene glycol intoxication

Diarrhoea

Renal tubular acidosis

Vomiting

Hyperaldosteronism

Loop or thiazide diuretics

Opiates, sedatives, anesthesia

Guillain- Barre syndrome, Polio, ALS, multiple sclerosis

Airway obstruction

Adult respiratory distress syndrome, COPD

Pneumonia, pulmonary embolism

High altitude

Psychogenic

Related Pearl: Expected compensation in acid-base disorders

Primary disorder Expected compensation
Metabolic acidosis

Expected PaCO2 = [1 .5 X HCO3-] + 8 ± 2; or

↓ PaCO2 = 1.25 x ΔHCO3
Metabolic alkalosis Increase in PaCO2 = 0.75 x ΔHCO3-

Respiratory acidosis
Acute

Increase in HCO3- = 0.1 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2
Chronic

Increase in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

↓ pH = 0.003 x ΔPaCO2

Respiratory alkalosis

Acute

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.2 x Δ PaCO2

↑ pH = 0.008 x ΔPaCO2

Chronic

Decrease in HCO3- = 0.4 x Δ PaCO2

questions.text: A patient presents with urinary frequency, nocturia, enuresis. 24 hr urine volume was done and found that it is greater than 3 litres. The urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. ADH assay was done and the values revealed 0.8 pg/ml. MRI of brain was done and the T1 weighted image did not reveal any abnormalities. The most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests Primary polydipsia.

Approach to the question :

  • Greater than 3 litres = Polyuria
  • Urine osmolality < 300 mOsm/ L = Diabetes insipidus, Primary polydipsia
  • Urine osmolality > 300 mOsm/ L = Solute loss (Mannitol infusion, Hypertonic saline)
  • ADH assay normal value = 1 pg/ml
  • ADH assay > 1 = Nephrogenic DI
  • ADH assay < 1 = Primary polydipsia , Central DI

To differentiate Central DI and Primary polydipsia , MRI brain should be done.

  • In case of Primary polydipsia , Pituitary bright spot will be seen.
  • In Central DI , Pituitary bright spot will be absent.

NOTE: In most healthy adults and children, the posterior pituitary emits a hyperintense signal visible in T1-weighted midsagittal images. This “bright spot” is almost always present in patients with primary polydipsia but is always absent
or abnormally small in patients with pituitary DI.

Therefore, when the question says that there were no abnormalities in the MRI, it just means that there is a pituitary bright spot present, because it is a finding seen even in healthy people and hence not considered an abnormality.

questions.text: A patient presents with headaches, palpitations and profuse sweating. He is a known case of Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2. On abdominal scan adrenal medullary tumors are revealed with size of 2.5 cm. The metabolite most likely involved in producing such symptoms is?
questions.solution:
Epinephrine is produced by small adrenal tumors.

Pheochromocytoma produces :

  • Norepinephrine  in
    • Extra adrenal tumors
    • Large adrenal tumors ( > 3 cm)
  • Epinephrine in
    • Small adrenal tumors ( < 3 cm)

questions.text: A 45 year old female presents with symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. The RAIU scan shows increased uptake. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Choriocarcinoma produces beta hCG which acts on TSH receptor to stimulate uptake of Iodine.

Hence RAIU would show increased uptake.

Option A.

Hashimoto’s thyroiditis

Any inflammation of thyroid will lead to reduced Uptake of Iodine.

Option B. & C.

Struma ovari and thyrotoxicosis factitia lead to reduced TSH leading to reduced uptake of iodine.

questions.text: SIADH may be seen in all of the following except
questions.solution:
SIADH may be seen in all of the above except Primary pulmonary emphysema.

Pulmonary causes of SIADH:

  • Asthma
  • Pneumonias (viral, bacterial, tuberculous)
  • Pneumothorax
  • Atelectasis
  • Acute Respiratory Faliure
  • Small cell Lung cancer

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady complains of weight gain and oligomenorrhea followed by amenorrhea for 8 months. Her blood pressure is measured to be 160/100 mm of Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests a diagnosis of Cushing’s disease which is diagnosed by Cortisol levels.

  • Weight gain with oligomenorrhea points to Cushing’s syndrome.
  • Cortisol inhibits gonadotropin release that explains amenorrhea.
  • Hypertension in these patients is secondary to increased cortisol that has some mineralocorticoid activity also.

questions.text: Best test for diagnosis of carcinoid tumor is
questions.solution:
• 5 Hydroxy Indole Acetic acid is a urinary metabolite of serotonin.
  • Serotonin and 5- HIAA are produced in excess by most carcinoid tumors.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: Most common cranial nerve involved in sarcoidosis:
questions.solution:
• The most common cranial nerve involved in Sarcoidosis is the seventh nerve, which can be affected bilaterally.
  • Nerve biopsy can reveal noncaseating granulomas infiltrating the endoneurium, perineurium, and epineurium along with lymphocytic necrotizing angiitis.
  • Neurosarcoidosis may respond to treatment with glucocorticoids or other immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text: A 25 year old man with 3 weeks fever presented with tricuspid valve vegetation. Patient is intravenous drug abuser. Most common cause of endocarditis in this patient is:
questions.solution:
Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of endocarditis in Intravenous drug users.

Related Pearl: Microbiology of Infective Endocarditis

 Condition

Most common organism

Most common organism overall

Staphylococcus aureus

Community-acquired native valve endocarditis

Streptococci

Healthcare-associated native valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Right side) Staphylococcus aureus
Endocarditis in injection drug users (Left side) Enterococci and Staphylococcus aureus

Single most common organism causing prosthetic valve endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Most common group of organism causing early prosthetic valve endocarditis (<12 months after surgery)

 

Coagulase-negative staphylococci (CoNS)*

Late prosthetic valve endocarditis (>12 months after surgery)

Streptococci

 

Acute infective endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus

Subacute infective endocarditis

Streptococcus viridans

Enterococci

Coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)

HACEK

Cardiovascular implantable electronic device (CIED)-associated endocarditis

Staphylococcus aureus  and coagulase-negative Staphylococci (CoNS)*

Culture negative endocarditis

Prior antibiotic use

Nutritionally variant streptococci

HACEK organisms

Coxiella burnetii

Bartonella

NOTE :

*CoNS includes Staphylococcus epidermidis and other coagulase-negative types

*Streptococci includes Viridans streptococci (VGS), Streptococcus gallolyticus (previously Streptococcus bovis biotype 1) and other non-groupable and groupable streptococci

 

Microorganism

Source

Streptococcus viridans

Oral cavity

Staphylococcus aureus

Skin

questions.text: Type of MODY associated with renal cyst is
questions.solution:
• MODY 5 is associated with renal cyst.
  • Most common type of MODY- MODY 3.

questions.text: The features given in the images is characteristic of
questions.solution:
• The image shows classical Keratoderma blenorrhagica which is an extra articular manifestation of reactive arthritis.
  • Previously this condition was called Reiter’s disease.

Other extra articular manifestations includes:

  • Uveitis
  • Diarrhoea

Articular manifestations include:

  • Asymmetrical oligo arthritis of large joint
  • Additive type of arthritis

Diagnosis:

  • Mostly Clinical , shows HLA B27 positivity

Treatment: 

  • First line- NSAIDS (>80% resolution) 
  • Start with sulphasalazine & Methotrexate if no resolution or if erosions are present

questions.text: Massive myoclonus is a hallmark of which stage of SSPE?
questions.solution:
Clinical stages of subacute sclerosis panencephalitis:

Stage  Clinical manifestations 
Stage I  Personality changes, failure in school, strange behaviour  
Stage II  Massive, repetitive, and frequent myoclonic jerks, seizures and dementia  
Stage III  Rigidity, extrapyramidal symptoms, and progressive unresponsiveness  
Stage IV  Coma, vegetative state, autonomic failure, and akinetic mutism

questions.text: Infraclavicular lesion of TB is called as
questions.solution:
Lesions in TB include:

  • Ghons focus - Beneath the pleura in the basal segment of the upper or apical segment of lower lobe.
  • Ghon complex - Ghon focus+ Involvement of regional lymph node.
  • Ghon lesions - Calcified healed primary TB lesions.
  • Ranke's complex - I/L calcified hilar lymphadenopathy with Ghon lesions.
  • Simon's focus - Apical scarring with appearance of fibronodular patch.
  • Puhl's lesion - Lesion at apex of lung in chronic TB.
  • Assmann focus - Infraclavicular lesion.
  • Rich focus - TB calcified foci in brain, meninges and spinal cord.

questions.text: Find the incorrect match of PFT value in the following regarding emphysema
questions.solution:
Compliance is increased in cases of emphysema as opposed to the other obstructive diseases.

PFT values in Emphysema:

Loss of lung elastic recoil- Hyperinflation leads to.

  • TLC-Increased.
  • RV-Increased.
  • FRC-Increased.
  • Severe elevation of RV leads to FVC-Decreased.
  • Loss of lung elastic recoil reduces the pressure driving maximal expiratory flow leads to.
  • FEV1- Decreased.
  • FEV1/FVC-Decreased.
  • DLCO- Decreased.
  • Compliance = Change in volume / Change in pressure.
  • Emphysema – compliance is increased(mainly static compliance is increased).

questions.text: The definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) includes all of the following, except:

choices.text: Undiagnosed after one week of investigation
Immuno compromised status should be ruled out
Fever persisting for more than 3 weeks

questions.solution:
The current definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) does not include undiagnosed after one week of investigation. The criterion "diagnosis uncertain, after 1 week of evaluation" which was previously a part of the definition has been removed.

FUO is currently defined as:

  • Fever ≥38.3°C (≥101°F) on at least two occasions 
  • Duration of ≥3 weeks
  • No known immunocompromised state
  • Diagnosis is uncertain after thorough history-taking, physical examination, and obligatory investigations.

Inflammation of Unknown Origin (IUO) is closely related to FUO. It has the same definition, except for the body temperature criterion. IUO is characterized by elevated inflammatory parameters (such as CRP or ESR) on multiple occasions for at least three weeks in an immunocompetent patient with normal body temperature. The causes and workups for IUO are similar to those for FUO.

questions.text: A diabetic patient who has developed chronic renal failure is prescribed a dipeptidyl-peptidase 4 (DPP4) inhibitor. No dose adjustment was done. Which of the following drugs was most likely prescribed to him?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, the drug that was most likely prescribed to this patient is linagliptin. It is a DPP-4 inhibitor that can be safely used in renal failure. It is mainly excreted through the hepatobiliary route.

DPP4 inhibitors are orally acting novel drugs that act by the incretin pathway and stimulate insulin secretion. These drugs have significantly lesser chances of hypoglycemic side effects. These drugs are mainly eliminated unchanged by the kidneys, except Linagliptin which is eliminated by the hepatobiliary route and is therefore considered relatively safer in a patient with renal failure.

 

 

Other options:

Option A: Dulaglutide is safe in renal failure, but it is a GLP-1 analog.

Option B: Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor but is excreted in the urine. The dose should be decreased in patients with renal failure.

Option D: Pramlintide is an amylin analog and can be used in moderate renal disease.

questions.text: Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is seen in
questions.solution:
Lymphangioleiomyomatosis (LAM) is seen in premenopausal females. ILD (Interstitial lung disease), in general, occur more commonly in women.


               Gender predisposition in ILDs

Women Men
Exclusively in premenopausal women:LAM Pulmonary involvement in Tuberous Sclerosis Pneumoconiosis (due to occupational exposure to asbestos, beryllium, and silica)
ILDs in association with CTD(connective tissue disorder) (except ILD is associated with rheumatoid arthritis) ILD is associated with rheumatoid arthritis 
  IPF (Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis)
  Pulmonary LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis)

Lymphangioleiomyomatosis

Seen in young women with recurrent pneumothorax or chylous effusion. The disease accelerates during pregnancy and abates after oophorectomy. HRCT shows thin-walled cysts surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. It is associated with meningioma. Marker: HMB-45.

questions.text: ANCA positivity is seen in
questions.solution:
ANCA (Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody) positivity is seen in certain types of vasculitis. There are 2 types: c ANCA and p ANCA                                                          

  c ANCA p ANCA
Location of ANCA Cytoplasmic Perinuclear
Target antigen Proteinase 3 Myeloperoxidase
Positive in: Wegener’s granulomatosis(Granulomatosis with polyangiitis) Microscopic polyangiitisChurg-Strauss syndrome

questions.text: Mucosal neuromas, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibres and megacolon are conditions associated with which of the following syndromes?
questions.solution:
MEN 2B is also called MEN 3. It arises from a mutation in RET protoncogene and is characterized by:
• Medullary thyroid cancer (>90%)
• Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
• Associated abnormalities;
• Mucosal neuromas
• Marfanoid habitus
• Medullated corneal nerve fibres
• Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors
